meanings.def: a strong border or structure of wood, metal, etc. that holds a picture, door, piece of glass, etc. in position
examples: a picture/photo frame
aluminium window frames
I'm going to paint the door frame white.
She leaned against the frame of the door.
in a frame pictures in gold frames

meanings.def: the supporting structure of a piece of furniture, a building, a vehicle, etc. that gives it its shape
examples: a bicycle frame
The bed frame is made of pine.
the frame of an aircraft/a car/a bicycle
In the 1920s, federal office buildings were typically built with steel frames encased in concrete or granite.

meanings.def: a structure of plastic or metal that holds the lenses in a pair of glasses
examples: gold-rimmed frames

meanings.def: the form or structure of a person or animal’s body
examples: to have a small/slender/large frame
The bed was shorter than his six-foot frame.
She has quite a small frame.
a man with a lean, athletic frame

meanings.def: the general ideas or structure that form the background to something
examples: in/within the frame of something In this course we hope to look at literature in the frame of its social and historical context.

meanings.def: one of the single photographs that a film or video is made of
a single picture in a comic strip
one of the separate areas on an internet page that you can scroll through (= read by moving the text up or down)
a small wooden or metal frame covered with glass that you grow seeds or small plants in to protect them from cold weather
a single section of play in the game of snooker, etc., or in bowling
examples: He won the first frame easily.

meanings.def: be taking part/not taking part in something
examples: We won our match, so we're still in the frame for the championship.

meanings.def: to be wanted/not wanted by the police because you are/are not suspected of having committed a crime
examples: He was always in the frame for the killing.

idioms.idiom: be in/out of the frame (for something)
idioms.def: be taking part/not taking part in something
examples: We won our match, so we're still in the frame for the championship.
He was always in the frame for the killing.

meanings.def: to put or make a frame or border around something
examples: be framed The photograph had been framed.
He was presented with a framed certificate.
(be) framed in something mirrors framed in silver and gold

meanings.def: to surround something/somebody in a way that makes an attractive image
examples: frame something/somebody I like the way your hair frames your face.
(be) framed against something He stood there, head back, framed against the blue sky.

meanings.def: to produce false evidence against an innocent person so that people think they are guilty
examples: be framed He says he was framed.
(be) framed for something She found herself framed for murder.

meanings.def: to create and develop something such as a plan, a system or a set of rules
examples: Measures to secure oil production must be framed in the context of rising energy demands.

meanings.def: to express something in a particular way
examples: You'll have to be careful how you frame the question.
